Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.

Sincerely,
Stephanie Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation

III. METHODOLOGY
11/30/2021 Special Investigation Intake 2022C0128009
11/30/2021 Special Investigation Initiated – Telephone Call with Complainant
12/01/2021 Inspection Completed On-site DCWL consultant initiated on-site
12/07/2021 Inspection Completed On-site Interviews with staff and youth
12/15/2021 Contact - Face to Face Interviews with Staff via TEAMS
12/16/2021 Contact - Document Received

01/12/2022 Pre-Exit Meeting
ALLEGATION:
Staff are putting Youth in unwarranted restraints.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on December 7,
2021. Chief Administrator said they have had Youth A in placement since May 2021.
Chief Administrator said since onset of placement Youth A has had ongoing
concerns with self-harm, suicidal ideation, assaults, destruction of property,
undressing and exposing herself to other youth, and attempting to AWOL. Chief
Administrator said recently Youth A’s behaviors have increased after another youth
in her house ingested perfume and was hospitalized and then spent six days in an
emergency placement. Chief Administrator said Youth A began to mimic the
behaviors of this other youth making statements about ingesting glass, cleaner, and
other materials in attempts to get hospitalized as well. Chief Administrator said
Youth A began breaking things around the house to ingest and breaking into the
office to get items to hurt herself in determination to be brought to the hospital. Chief
Administrator said due to Youth A’s self-report that she had swallowed different
objects she had to be brought to the emergency room for evaluation. Chief
Administrator said Youth A was always sent back to Eagle Village and not
hospitalized. Chief Administrator said due to these increased incidents it was
decided a new behavior support plan needed to be developed to keep Youth A safe.
Chief Administrator said the Program Director, Therapist, house supervisor, foster
care worker, GAL and herself were involved in the development of the behavior
2

support plan and the Judge for Youth A was also made aware of the plan for Youth
A. Chief Administrator discussed the expectations of Youth A with the new behavior
support plan, which is noted in the section “documents” below. Chief Administrator
said Youth A had an increase in behaviors at first however they have seen a
decrease in her issues recently and she is showing progress. Chief Administrator
said since being on the current behavior support plan Youth A has finally been able
to start sleeping in her own room without issue and has started to disclose
information on past traumas. Chief Administrator said they have tried to use many
other tools and plans to support Youth A however due to her increased behaviors
they felt the new behavior support plan was the only way to keep her safe at this
time. Chief Administrator said the new behavior support plan went into effect on
November 24, 2021, and Youth A was still in an obsessive state of self-harm which
led to the restraints on November 25, 2021. Chief Administrator said staff were
updating her daily over the Thanksgiving weekend and she was aware of the
restraints on November 25, 2021, as well as the concerns/progress Youth A had
over the weekend on the behavior support plan. Chief Administrator said she,
Program Director, Therapist, house supervisor and Youth A have reviewed the
behavior plan three times between November 24, 2021, and December 7, 2021, with
another review set for today (12/7/21).
Program Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on December 7,
2021. Program Director said Youth A has been in the program since the spring and
has had many concerns since that time. Program Director said since October 1,
2021, Youth A has had 26 assaults to staff/peers, 30 suicide incidents, 7 sexually
inappropriate incidents, and 17 out of bound/property damage/medical refusal
issues. Program Director said Youth A’s team has tried many different tools with
Youth A to provide her support and treatment since her placement. Program Director
sat in on the interviews with Chief Administrator and Therapist and in speaking with
her afterwards she agreed with the information they both provided as far as Youth
A’s history while in the program and current needs for the behavior support plan.
Program Director also confirmed she understood all licensing rules for when
restraints are to be utilized.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on December 7, 2021.
Therapist said she has been assigned to work with Youth A since May 27, 2021.
Therapist said since Youth A arrived, she has shown extreme behaviors and will
dysregulate from 0 to 100 in seconds. Therapist said since placement at Eagle
Village Youth A has broken windows on building and vehicles, assaulted peers and
staff, self-harmed, disrobed and ran around campus, and attempted to AWOL.
Therapist said recently, Youth A has shown an increased desire to self-harm and
has become more impulsive. Therapist said Youth A does not have a “traditional
look of dysregulation” and therefore it is more difficult for staff to see when Youth A
is triggered. Therapist said along with this concern and her impulsivity staff have
struggled to intervene prior to Youth A beginning to self-harm. Therapist said the
nature of self-harm has also increased for Youth A as she has tried to drink cleaner,
perfume, swallow glass or other objects. Therapist said Youth A has been brought to
3

the hospital several times for ingesting cleaner for the white board at school, saying
she swallowed glass, and other self-harm behaviors and each time has been
evaluated and will change her story therefore sent back to Eagle Village. Therapist
said previously they have tried other coping methods with Youth A such as a
weighted blanket, slime, or other tools however Youth A’s behaviors have increased
and her willingness to use her coping tools have decreased. Therapist said based on
the extremeness and impulsiveness of her behavior is the reason why it was
decided Youth A needed a more intense behavior support plan. Therapist said the
plan was discussed with her, Chief Administrator, Program Director and then shared
with the foster care worker and the GAL who both were in support of the behavior
support plan for Youth A. Therapist said the behavior support plan is intended to
keep Youth A safe, break the negative behaviors that Youth A has established, learn
her own triggers of distress or negative feelings, and help Youth A realize the staff
can keep her safe from herself. Therapist said the behavior support plan has Youth
A sitting at the table doing activities throughout the day such as therapy sheets,
coloring, or crafts, with build in breaks to go on a walk and have time in her
bedroom. Therapist said Youth A’s bedroom was “stripped” of anything unsafe and
does not need to be searched prior to her going into her bedroom for her break.
Therapist said there is a meeting at least weekly with the house supervisor, Chief
Administrator, Program Director, Youth A and herself to discuss the safety plan and
how Youth A is progressing and slowly opening Youth A’s plan up to her being on a
normal schedule with the other youth and off her plan. Therapist said in her opinion
this has been a successful safety plan for Youth A. Therapist said since the safety
plan has been in place the incidents with Youth A have decreased, her ability to
regulate herself without restraints has increased, and Youth A is beginning to open
up about her past traumas. Therapist said Youth A is involved in the meetings and
has shown progress during the meetings being able to participate and ask for
additional items she would like back. Therapist said Youth A made a disclosure
about past sexual abuse and she was able to stay self-regulated throughout the
entire shift which was “huge” for Youth A. Therapist said she believed the safety plan
would only be needed a couple of weeks in order to get Youth A to a place where
she could be back on the normal house schedule. Therapist said despite the normal
rules regarding restraint, she felt Youth A needed this plan in order to keep Youth A
safe.
I participated in the behavior support review meeting with Youth A face-to-face
on December 7, 2021. Prior to the meeting, Therapist and Program Director
reported to me, Youth A has a pattern of becoming dysregulated and ultimately often
restrained after being interviewed by DCWL or other DHHS employees. Therefore, it
was decided I would participate in the review of the behavior support plan in order to
obtain information from Youth A in a safe setting that would not trigger increased
behavioral issues for her. Youth A presented well-groomed, in clean clothing, with a
positive mood. Youth A said she was on the safety plan due to swallowing glass,
spiting/biting/hitting others, and hurting herself with anything she can find. Youth A
said she is trying every day to “do better”, ask permission before doing things, and
think about her actions before just “doing them”. Youth A said she did get in a hold
4

recently for threatening to hurt herself and staff but then went back to her seat at the
table and played games with staff. Youth A said she is learning not to hurt herself
and staff and said she “likes myself when I am being good” and she feels good
“because people treat me respectful”. Youth A said she feels happy and wants to
start doing more “stuff”. Youth A said she used to spit on staff, hurt herself or others,
and is having decreased incidents at this time. Youth A said she thinks sitting at the
table is working to help her stay safe. Youth A said she feels she needs a “safe
space” and things she should continue to have “table time” but that she wants to do
other activities with her peers as well.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face via TEAMS on December 15, 2021. Staff
1said she was working on November 25, 2021. Staff 1 said Youth A said she wanted
a break in her room and per the safety plan she is allowed to do this but needs to be
monitored. Staff 1 said she told Youth A that she needed to wait for a bit before
going to her room so that they could get the staffing in place. Staff 1 said Youth A
went down to her bedroom without permission and making threats to self-harm while
walking down the hallway. Staff 1 said she followed Youth A to her room and Youth
A began banging her head on the wall. Staff 1 asked for assistance and Staff 2 and
Staff 3 came down the hallway to help. Staff 1 said she then went to watch the other
youth. Staff 1 said she did not see what happened during the restraint. Staff 1 said
Youth A is on a safety plan where she is to stay at the table and only can get up with
staff permission, otherwise she is to be put in a restraint. Staff 1 said she was
informed of the safety plan from Therapist and the house supervisor. Staff 1 said the
safety plans are also in a staff binder which the staff review, date and sign, as well
as verbally shared with staff.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face via TEAMS on December 15, 2021. Staff 2
said she does not normally work in the same house as Youth A but was picking up a
shift on November 25, 2021. Staff 2 said she was told about Youth A’s safety plan by
house supervisor, Therapist, read it in the house binder, and was sent an email with
Youth A’s plan. Staff 2 said she came out of the bathroom and was called down to
Youth A’s bedroom by Staff 1 because Youth A was in the bedroom without
permission and refused to leave her room. Staff 2 said she attempted to talk with
Youth A and get her to go back down to the table however Youth A refused, stood
up and ran up the ladder to the top bunk in her room. Staff 2 said she told Youth A to
come down, but Youth A refused. Staff 3 began to climb the ladder and Youth A
started to swing her fists and spit on Staff 3. Staff 2 said Staff 3 was able to get
Youth A off the top bunk and she and Staff 3 put Youth A in a safety seated position.
Staff 2 said Youth A was headbutting, kicking her legs, and spitting during the
restraint. Staff 2 said during the restraint she and Staff 3 were talking Youth A
“down”. Staff 2 said Youth A headbutted her in the mouth and so she switched out
with Staff 1 and went to check her mouth in the bathroom. Staff 2 said when she
came back from the bathroom Youth A was calm and she walked back to the table
to her seat. Staff 2 said she verbally reminded Youth A she needed to be seated at
the table unless she has staff permission to get up. Staff 2 said about fifteen minutes
after Youth A had sat down, she got back up from the table without staff permission.
5

Staff 2 said she told Youth A to sit down, and she did not so Staff 2 restrained her,
walked Youth A back to her seat, and Youth A sat back down. Staff 2 said the
restraint was done due to Youth A’s safety plan stating that if Youth A gets up from
the table without permission she is to be restrained. Staff 2 said she does not know
why Youth A has even stood up at that time but did not resist the restraint and
willingly sat back in her seat. Staff 2 said she has not worked with Youth A since that
date.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face via TEAMS on December 15, 2021. Staff 3
said he is the up-night supervisor and was on call on November 25, 2021 and was
working in Youth A’s house from 5pm-9pm that evening. Staff 3 said he is aware of
Youth A’s safety plan and was told about it during a supervisor meeting on
November 24, 2021. Staff 3 said he was in the house when all the staff and youth
came back from dinner. Staff 3 said Youth A went down to her room, came back,
and then went back to her room. Staff 3 said he was called down to Youth A’s
bedroom by Staff 1 and when he arrived Youth A was sitting on her bed. Staff 3 said
Staff 2 came down to Youth A’s bedroom as well. Staff 3 said he and Staff 2 were
talking with Youth A but she just kept getting louder and louder and then got up from
the bottom bunk and moved to the top bunk. Staff 3 said he was not sure if Youth A
had anything on the top bunk that could pose a safety risk and so he began to climb
the ladder behind Youth A. Staff 3 said Youth A spit on his face and began to hit
Staff 2. Staff 3 said he and Staff 2 each took one of Youth A’s arms and got Youth A
down and she dropped weight and went to the floor and was struggling. Staff 3 said
Staff 2 had Youth A in a seated safety position and Staff 3 was on Youth A’s legs.
Staff 3 said Youth A headbutted Staff 2 in the face and so he switched and took
Youth A’s arms and Staff 2 went on Youth A’s legs. Staff 3 said he had a tight hold
on Youth A, so she was unable to headbutt him. Staff 3 said prior to the restraint
there were many attempts to verbally deescalate Youth A however she kept “amping
back up”. Staff 3 said Youth A began to become aggressive with hitting and kicking
which is what lead to the restraint. Staff 3 said he was in the house but not in the
kitchen/dining room during the second restraint with Staff 2 and Youth A.
During the interview with Staff 3, he mentioned Youth B is “on the same type of plan”
as Youth A. Staff 3 said that Youth B is also expected to sit at the table for “table
time” due to her safety plan.
Documents Reviewed:
 Behavior Support Plan for Youth A created on 8/23/2021 which is as follows:
o Purpose: Youth A has poor boundaries with staff and her peers. It
appears she uses sexual behaviors to have control of situations. Youth
A has on a number of instances taken her clothes off when she is
upset. She then does various sexual behaviors (i.e., “twerking,”
rubbing her hands on her vagina, asked to be “fucked”, runs through
the campus naked). There is a need to protect Youth A’s dignity and
modesty when she is upset as well as protect the other youth on
campus from being triggered. It is in the regard the following plan is to
6

be initiated and followed. Additionally, Youth A has been picking up
rocks causing damage to property, breaking windows (leaving glass for
others to use to self-harm), and assault staff. This is a significant safety
risk, not just for Youth A but for the other youth and staff.
 When Youth A is beginning to get upset (noted by her telling
staff she is going to AWOLP, begins threating, or begins telling
staff she is refusing) staff are to remind her:
 Of her sticker program and the rewards she is wanting.
 Staff are to encourage Youth A to use:
 Time in the Sensory Room
 The Weighted Blanket
 Ask to go to the swings
 Ask for a “5”
 If Youth A refuses these things staff are to maintain eyes on
 If Youth A begins to pick up rocks, demonstrates she is
beginning to take her cloths off, or is within 20 feet of any
building or vehicle staff are to utilize the following immediately:
 Mirror and matching
 Use an escort
 Place in the Therapeutic restraint
 If the use of restraint is needed, staff are to remain in the hold
with Youth A until she is fully calm. This will prevent her from
engaging in unsafe behaviors immediately after she is released
from the restraint (as is her practice).
 Staff are to follow all Eagle Village’s policy and procedures in
regard to restraints.
 Safety Plan for Youth A created on 11/19/2021 which is as follows:
o Purpose: Youth A is mirroring some of the other girls in the house in
her talk and behaviors. She is ingesting perfume and on Tuesday
drank dry eraser board cleaner. She was taken to the ER and
assessed by CMH. They believe this is not a psychiatric issue but a
behavioral one. Youth A continues to struggle with impulsive behaviors
therefore she will be on a safety plan with 5-minute checks.
o The following is the safety plan:
 All items will be removed from the youth’s room, except for a
pillow (pillowcase need to be removed) and comforter,
immediately upon being placed on Close Observation. (This is
for suicidal ideation only so youth cannot use bed sheets or
pillowcases as a means of suicide).
 Bedroom door is to remain open at all times.
 Youth Should remain in staff eyesight and close proximity to
staff (with the exception to private/sleeping times) will only use
their bedrooms to sleep. They are not to hang out down the
hallways on Close Obs.
7

 The youth should be encouraged to participate in all program
activities. Youth should have a designated staff to observe them
during the program activities.
 Staff will accompany youth to the bathroom. Staff will “pocket
check” the youth before entering the bathroom. They will check
the bathroom for any potential objects that could be used to
inflict harm. When using the bathroom or shower, the staff will
check on the youth every two minutes. Staff will initiate
conversation or ask the youth a question through the door. If the
youth does not respond, staff will enter the bathroom to ensure
the youth is safe.
 At quiet time and bedtime, a staff will present in the hallway with
the focus on directly supervising that youth, until the youth falls
asleep, with the door open.
 Once the youth is asleep, staff does not need to sit directly
outside their door, however; staff must continue variable checks
within 5 minutes from the last check, this will be documented on
the 5 Minute Log. Example: If staff were sitting outside the
youth’s door from 11pm-3am, they only need to write down
“sitting outside door from 11pm-3am” in the 5 minute log. They
do not have to write that every 5 minutes. Once 5 minute checks
resume, then staff document each 5 minute check on the log.
 If further issues/concerns arise with this youth, the on call
therapist will be contacted again.
 Behavior Support Plan for Youth A created on 11/24/2021which is as follows:
o Purpose: Youth A has demonstrated through her behaviors she is
incapable of keeping herself safe. She claims she has ingested
anything that she can find (i.e., beads, perfume, glass, cleaner). This
has been an ongoing pattern with incidents (of attempting to break into
the office to gain access to these things as well as ingesting items)
occurring on (11/01/2021, 11/02/2021, 11/07/2021, 11/07/2021,
11/13/2021, 11/15/2021, 11/15/2021, 11/15/2021, 11/15/2021,
11/16/2021, 11/16/2021, 11/17/2021, 11/17/2021, 11/17/2021,
11/18/2021, 11/18/2021, 11/19/2021, 11/20/2021, 11/20/2021,
11/21/2021, 11/21/2021, 11/24/2021). It is believed these actions are
not a result of suicidal ideation but rather, behavioral in nature. As a
result of these instances the Sherk house quickly becomes
dysregulated. There is a need to protect Youth A from continued
hurting herself.
o The following plan will occur:
 Youth A will be stationed at the Sherk kitchen table.
 While at the table she will be allowed crayons, paper, and
therapeutic worksheets assigned by the therapist.
 A schedule will be provided and followed. The schedule will
provide Youth A with the following:
8

 One walk in the morning and one walk in the evening.
This will be on the Eagle Village road – from Sherk house
to the stop sign by the Hainley Field.
 One hour of alone time in her bedroom in the afternoon
with the staff at the bedroom and bedroom door open.
 Allowed to use the bathroom when the need arises,
following these steps:
o Bathroom is to be checked for unsafe items
o Youth A will be check for unsafe items
o The bathroom stall door will remain open with staff
able to monitor without a direct line of sight to
keep modestly and dignity.
o Staff will keep eyes on the duration of the
bathroom use
 If Youth A attempts to get up from the table without permission
staff will do the following:
 Place in the Therapeutic Restraint
 If the use of restraint is needed, staff are to remain in the hold
with Youth A until she is fully calm. This will prevent her from
engaging in unsafe behaviors immediately after she is released
from the restraint (as is her practice).
 Staff are to follow all Eagle Village’s policy and procedures in
regards to restraints.
o Addendum to this plan (no date) was as follows: Youth A met with the
administrative team this morning about her continued behaviors. She
was in numerous restraints throughout the weekend due to her
unwillingness to comply with expectations. She continues to
demonstrate a lack of ability to manage her emotions, respect those
around her and keep herself safe. She will remain on this program
though Friday 12/3/2021.
o Addendum to this plan dated 12/3/2021 was as follows: Youth A met
with the administrative team this morning. She has demonstrated she
is capable of keeping herself safe. She still has some work to do in this
area though. Due to her ability to go over 24 hours without the need of
restraint of self-harming, the following modifications are made:
 Youth A is still to remain at the table during free time
 If there is an activity going on she may ask the staff if she may
join. It is at the staff discretion if she does and is based on her
compliance.
 Youth A may have an extra 15 minutes in the morning and
evening of outside time. This 15 minutes is to allow her to play
and should be restricted to Sherk areas.
 If she is demonstrating safe behaviors, she may go on the van
ride to the Saturday night off campus activity.
 Continues safe behaviors will allow her to go to the church
dinner on Sunday.
9

 These privs can be revoked for unsafe behaviors.
o Addendum to this plan dated 12/7/2021 was as follows: Youth A met
with the administrative team. Youth A has demonstrated she is able to
keep herself and other safe. She had minor issues but was able to quickly
reregulate. Due to this Youth A has earned the following modifications:
 Youth A will remain at the table with the above expectations
 Youth A will be allowed to wear her own clothes
 Youth A will be able to have her salt rock night light in her room
when she goes to bed and is to return it in the morning.
 Aside from her personal clothing, these privs can be restricted if
Youth A is not activity being safe.
 Behavior Support Plan for Youth B created on 11/24/2021which is as follows:
o Purpose: Youth B has demonstrated through her behaviors she is
incapable of keeping herself safe. She claims she has ingested
anything that she can find (i.e., beads, perfume, glass, cleaner). This
has been an ongoing pattern with incidents occurring on (11/01/2021,
11/01/2021, 11/01/2021, 11/03/2021, 11/03/2021, 11/03/2021,
11/4/2021, 11/13/2021, 11/15/2021, 11/15/2021, 11/20/2021,
11/21/2021, 11/23/2021, and 11/24/2021). It is believed these actions
are not a result of suicidal ideation but rather, behavioral in nature.
Youth B is capable of processing, and knows the expectations and the
difference between right and wrong. As a result of these instances the
Sherk house quickly become dysregulated. There is a need to protect
Youth B from continued hurting herself.
o The following plan will occur:
 Youth B will be stationed at the Sherk kitchen table.
 While at the table she will be allowed crayons, paper and
therapeutic worksheets assigned by the therapist.
 A schedule will provided and followed. The schedule will provide
Youth B with the following:
 One walk in the morning and one walk in the evening.
This will be on the Eagle Village road – from the Sherk
house to the stop sign by the Hainley Field.
 One hour of alone time in her bedroom in the afternoon
with the staff at the bedroom and the bedroom door
open.
 Allowed to use the bathroom when the need arises,
following these steps:
o Bathroom is to be checked for unsafe items
o Youth B will be checked for unsafe items
o The bathroom stall door will remain open with staff
able to monitor without a direct line of sight to
keep modestly and dignity.
o Staff will keep eyes on the duration of the
bathroom use.
10

 If Youth B attempts to get up from the table without permission
staff will do the following:
 Mirror and matching
 Use an escort
 Place in the Therapeutic restraint
 If the use of restraint is needed, staff are to remain in the hold
with Youth B until she is fully calm. This will prevent her from
engaging in unsafe behaviors immediately after she is released
from the restraint (as is her practice).
 Staff are to follow all Eagle Village’s policy and procedures in
regards to restraints.
o Addendum (date unknown):
 Youth B demonstrated an ability to keep herself safe and out of
chaos. Because she has demonstrated this for over 48 hours
she will be allowed the following additions to her plan:
 15 minutes outside on the swings or sitting at the picnic
table
 15 extra minutes in her bedroom
 A ten minute phone conversation with her grandmother
o Addendum dated 11/29/2021:
 Youth B continues to demonstrate she is willing to help herself
remain safe. She met with the administrative review team this
morning. She is willing to comply with the same expectations in
the school as at the Sherk house, understanding she is
responsible for her actions and is capable of keeping herself
safe. Youth B desire the additional of the following privileges to
her pan:
 She will be able to be with the other youth in the
classroom, and will take assigned breaks as staff are
available.
 She will be allowed to have her Sudoku book to work on
while at the table
 She will be allowed to have her Sherlock Holms book to
read while at the table.
o Addendum dated 11/30/2021:
 Youth B continues to make progress in her program and in her
behaviors. She has been able to remain in school and in class.
She met all expectations. The following are the privileges she
has earned:
 She will remain at the table. However, she may ask to
join others in activities (game time, walks, movies, help
cook dinner etc.). Staff have the option to tell her yes or
no depending on what is going on in the house.
 She may have the shower door closed – but still needs to
be given her shampoo and body wash by staff.
 She may use her MP3 player while at the table
11

 She may wear her own clothing

 Eagle Village Therapeutic Holds Procedure. This procedures states “The only
approved therapeutic hold techniques are the methods and techniques taught
in the required Aegis course and should only be used when a resident is a
harm to themselves or others, or as a precaution against escape where the
youth may be at risk of injury to self or others, and/or after all verbal de-

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures regarding restraint. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
(4) The written policy shall only permit the licensee to
restraint a child for the following circumstances:
(a) To prevent injury to the child, self-injury, or injury to
others.
(b) As a precaution against escape or truancy.
(c) When there is serious destruction of property that
places a child or others at serious threat of violence or
injury if no intervention occurs.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance of resident restraint.
Eagle Village has a policy/procedure which outlines when the
staff are allowed to restraint a youth and the behavior support
plan for Youth A violates the internal procedure by directing staff
to restraint Youth A whenever she gets up from the table without
permission as confirmed during staff interviews. Due to this
directive, there have been restraints performed on Youth A that
are unwarranted per the rule as Youth A is not actively
attempting to harm herself or others, escaping, or causing
serious destruction of property when the restraints have been
initiated.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
